Erythroid lineage and developmental stage specificities .

Transcriptional regulation of the human alpha-like globin genes , embryonic zeta 2 and adult alpha , during erythroid development is mediated by a distal enhancer , <extra_id_0> HS-40 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

Previous protein - DNA binding studies have shown that <extra_id_0> HS-40 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> consists of multiple nuclear factor binding motifs that are occupied in vivo in an erythroid lineage - and developmental stage - specific manner .

We have systematically analyzed the functional roles of these factor binding motifs of <extra_id_0> HS-40 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> by site - directed mutagenesis and transient expression assay in erythroid cell cultures .

Three of these <extra_id_0> HS-40 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> enhancer motifs , 5'NF-E2 / AP1 , GT II , and <extra_id_0> GATA-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( c ) , positively regulate the <extra_id_0> zeta 2-globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter activity in embryonic / fetal erythroid K562 cells and the <extra_id_0> adult alpha-globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter activity in adult erythroid MEL cells .

On the other hand , the 3'NF-E2 / AP1 motif is able to exert both positive and negative regulatory effects on the <extra_id_0> zeta 2-globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter activity in K562 cells , and this dual function appears to be modulated through differential binding of the ubiquitous AP1 factors and the erythroid-enriched NF-E2 factor .

Mutation in the <extra_id_0> GATA-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( d ) motif , which exhibits an adult erythroid - specific genomic footprint , decreases the <extra_id_0> HS-40 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> enhancer function in dimethyl sulfoxide - induced MEL cells but not in K562 cells .
These studies have defined the regulatory roles of the different <extra_id_0> HS-40 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> motifs .

The remarkable correlation between genomic footprinting data and the mutagenesis results also suggests that the erythroid lineage - and developmental stage - specific regulation of human alpha-like globin promoters is indeed modulated by stable binding of specific nuclear factors in vivo .
